newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Kenmare denies BHP takeover interest.
newsitem.headline: Kenmare denies BHP takeover interest.

text.p: Irish exploration company Kenmare Resources Plc on Tuesday denied market rumours that its joint venture partner BHP was going to make a bid for Kenmare.
"As far as we are aware no approach has been made to us by BHP, nor are we aware of any intention by them to make an approach," company secretary Tony McCluskey told Reuters.

McCluskey said he had spoken with the Irish stock exchange on the matter and he said he had given it a similar response in that, as far as Kenmare was aware, no bid was being prepared, had been prepared or had been entered into on behalf of BHP for Kenmare.
Kenmare and BHP entered into a joint venture in July 1996 covering exploration and possible development of the Congolone Mineral Sands Project in northern Mozambique.
At the time of the announcement an estimated resource of 50.5 million tonnes of ilmenite was identified.

"We are in a very significant joint venture with BHP and that is the extent of our involvement with BHP. It is probably not fully understood by the market as it is a relatively complex area," McCluskey said.

The joint venture agreement entitles BHP to earn a 75 percent interest in the project by spending $24 million. However, BHP's participation was contingent on the continued success of the exploration programme.
"To build that project you are probably talking in the order of $300 million plus and since the announcement we have made very good progress with BHP," McCluskey said.
"They (BHP) have continued to advance their involvement and to advance their drilling programmes and as far as I am aware they are planning another drilling programme for 1997," McCluskey said.
